title: Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer and Black People
author: Alyson Powell Key

content: The yearly rate of new lung cancer cases in the United States continues to decline, and advances in screening and research are helping more people survive the disease. The 5-year survival rate has risen 22% in the past 5 years.  The current survival rate is now nearly 27%.

Unfortunately, lung cancer is still the number one cause of cancer deaths in the U.S. and globally. But communities of color have a lower survival rate. For Black Americans, the 5-year survival rate is just 21%. And in the African American community, tobacco use is one of the top causes of preventable death.

content_blocks.text: The yearly rate of new lung cancer cases in the United States continues to decline, and advances in screening and research are helping more people survive the disease. The 5-year survival rate has risen 22% in the past 5 years.  The current survival rate is now nearly 27%.

Unfortunately, lung cancer is still the number one cause of cancer deaths in the U.S. and globally. But communities of color have a lower survival rate. For Black Americans, the 5-year survival rate is just 21%. And in the African American community, tobacco use is one of the top causes of preventable death.

sections.heading: Small-Cell and Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer
content: Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) and non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) are the two main types of the disease. NSCLC makes up around 85% of all lung cancer diagnoses. NSCLCs are cancers that form in the cells lining your lung airways. They happen when abnormal cells in your lungs quickly multiply and grow unchecked. A significant number of NSCLCs (40%) have spread to different parts of the body by the time you get a lung cancer diagnosis.

content_blocks.text: Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) and non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) are the two main types of the disease. NSCLC makes up around 85% of all lung cancer diagnoses. NSCLCs are cancers that form in the cells lining your lung airways. They happen when abnormal cells in your lungs quickly multiply and grow unchecked. A significant number of NSCLCs (40%) have spread to different parts of the body by the time you get a lung cancer diagnosis.

sections.heading: Lung Cancer Rates Among Black Americans
content: The latest numbers from the C DC show that doctors diagnosed nearly 22,500 Black Americans with lung and bronchus cancer in 2021. J ust over 14,000 Black people lost their lives to these diseases in 2022 . Lung and bronchus cancer is the third leading type of cancer among Black Americans, behind prostate and breast cancers. It’s also the deadliest form of the disease for this group.

In past years, Black Americans had the highest annual rate of new lung cancers across all races and ethnicities in the U.S. Today,  this population has the third-highest rate, just slightly lower than White Americans, American Indians/Alaska Natives. Here’s a breakdown by race and ethnicity:
When you look at the numbers by sex, Black men have the highest rate of lung and bronchus cancer in the U.S.

sections.heading: Cigarette and Cigar Smoking
content: Smoking tobacco is linked to around 90% of lung cancer cases in the U.S . Other triggers include secondhand smoke , asbestos , and radon gas .
Overall, 16.8% of Black Americans smoke, compared to 16.6% of White Americans, 21.9% of American Indians/Alaska Natives, 7.0% of Asian Americans, and 10.1% of Hispanic Americans.

While Black Americans have a slightly higher smoking rate than White Americans, this group smokes menthol, or minty-flavored cigarettes at much higher rates than any other race or ethnicity. Here’s a look at the percentage of smokers who say menthols are their cigarette of choice:

Menthol covers up the harsh taste of cigarette smoke. This type of flavoring makes it easier to light up – and light up more often. People who smoke menthols tend to smoke more cigarettes and inhale more deeply than those who smoke unflavored types. It also makes it more challenging to quit – meaning you’re more likely to become dependent. All of these things can raise your chances of lung cancer and other smoking-related illnesses.

content_blocks.text: Smoking tobacco is linked to around 90% of lung cancer cases in the U.S . Other triggers include secondhand smoke , asbestos , and radon gas .
Overall, 16.8% of Black Americans smoke, compared to 16.6% of White Americans, 21.9% of American Indians/Alaska Natives, 7.0% of Asian Americans, and 10.1% of Hispanic Americans.

While Black Americans have a slightly higher smoking rate than White Americans, this group smokes menthol, or minty-flavored cigarettes at much higher rates than any other race or ethnicity. Here’s a look at the percentage of smokers who say menthols are their cigarette of choice:

Menthol covers up the harsh taste of cigarette smoke. This type of flavoring makes it easier to light up – and light up more often. People who smoke menthols tend to smoke more cigarettes and inhale more deeply than those who smoke unflavored types. It also makes it more challenging to quit – meaning you’re more likely to become dependent. All of these things can raise your chances of lung cancer and other smoking-related illnesses.

content: Similarly, tobacco companies use flavors like grape, cherry, and vanilla in cigars. Young Black people tend to smoke flavored cigars at higher rates than cigarettes.
In April 2022, the FDA proposed ending the sale of menthol cigarettes and flavored cigars. Once the proposal is approved, tobacco companies will have a year to remove these products.

content_blocks.text: Similarly, tobacco companies use flavors like grape, cherry, and vanilla in cigars. Young Black people tend to smoke flavored cigars at higher rates than cigarettes.
In April 2022, the FDA proposed ending the sale of menthol cigarettes and flavored cigars. Once the proposal is approved, tobacco companies will have a year to remove these products.

sections.heading: Understanding Health Inequities
content: Health inequities play a major role in many illnesses, including lung cancer. These imbalances, based on things like race and ethnicity, can determine your health and overall quality of life.

In certain communities, health inequities can begin even before a lung cancer diagnosis . For decades, tobacco companies have aimed cigarette marketing – particularly menthol cigarettes – toward the Black community. This has played a part in health disparities. Researchers estimate that if tobacco companies stopped selling menthol cigarettes, nearly 250,000 Black Americans would stop smoking within 17 months.

After a cancer diagnosis, Black Americans living with the disease have worse health outcomes than white Americans. According to the American Lung Association, when compared to white people, Black Americans are:
bullets: 15% less likely to get an early diagnosis
11% more likely to go without treatment

After a cancer diagnosis, Black Americans living with the disease have worse health outcomes than white Americans. According to the American Lung Association, when compared to white people, Black Americans are:
associated_bullets: 15% less likely to get an early diagnosis
11% more likely to go without treatment

content: Compared to other ethnic groups, Black Americans are:

These numbers likely contribute to lower survival rates for Black people with early-stage non-small-cell lung cancer. This group is the least likely of any racial or ethnic group to live 5 years after diagnosis. Closing the health disparity gap would be a major step toward improving the health of Black Americans with lung cancer and other illnesses.
bullets: About as likely as Hispanic or Asian Americans to get an early diagnosis
23% less likely than Hispanic Americans and 32% less likely than Asian Americans to have surgery
Almost 17% less likely than Hispanic Americans and 4% more likely than Asian Americans to go without treatment
Statistically about as likely as Indigenous/Native Americans to get an early diagnosis, have surgery, or go without treatment

content_blocks.text: Compared to other ethnic groups, Black Americans are:
associated_bullets: About as likely as Hispanic or Asian Americans to get an early diagnosis
23% less likely than Hispanic Americans and 32% less likely than Asian Americans to have surgery
Almost 17% less likely than Hispanic Americans and 4% more likely than Asian Americans to go without treatment
Statistically about as likely as Indigenous/Native Americans to get an early diagnosis, have surgery, or go without treatment

content_blocks.text: These numbers likely contribute to lower survival rates for Black people with early-stage non-small-cell lung cancer. This group is the least likely of any racial or ethnic group to live 5 years after diagnosis. Closing the health disparity gap would be a major step toward improving the health of Black Americans with lung cancer and other illnesses.

sections.heading: Advances in Lung Cancer Prevention
content: Researchers are finding new ways to detect lung cancer. We now know that screening for the illness every year can help doctors pinpoint tumors at an earlier stage and save more lives. Experts say annual low-dose CT scans can lower the rate of lung cancer deaths by up to 20%.

In March 2021, the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) updated its guidance for lung cancer screening. The task force now advises younger smokers (starting at age 50), those who have smoked at least one pack a day for 20 years (two packs a day for 10 years, and so on) and currently smoke, or who have quit smoking within the past 15 years to get an annual lung cancer screening. These updated guidelines have raised the number of Black Americans in the “high-risk” category for developing lung cancer and eligible for screening.

sources: CDC: “Cancer Statistics At a Glance,” “Changes Over Time: Lung and Bronchus,” “Leading Cancers by Age, Sex, Race and Ethnicity.”
Clinical Lung Cancer : “Evidence That Established Lung Cancer Mortality Disparities in American Indians Are Not Due to Lung Cancer Genetic Testing and Targeted Therapy Disparities.”

American Lung Association: “State of Lung Cancer 2021: Lung Cancer Key Findings,” “State of Lung Cancer 2021: Racial and Ethnic Disparities,” “Tell Congress to Invest in Defeating Lung Cancer!” “Cigarette Smoking Comparisons and Disparities,” “What’s Happening with Menthol Cigarettes and How Does it Impact Me?”
MD Anderson Cancer Center: “Menthol cigarettes: The FDA's proposed ban and why they’re more harmful.”
Cancer Control : “Racial and Ethnic Differences in the Epidemiology of Lung Cancer and the Lung Cancer Genome.”
meta_description: More people are surviving lung cancer, but Black people continue to face lower survival rates. Find out why and how to turn this statistic around.
